urn:contentItem:6GGF-C003-RRPY-C2DV-00000-00Kawartha Lakes fires: How to see where fires are burning and which areas to avoid2025-08-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Kawartha Lakes fires: How to see where fires are burning and which areas to avoidMetroland Staff

Parts of Kawartha Lakes and surrounding communities are experiencing forest fires, which have been happening for several days and are continuing today (Monday, Aug. 11).

If you are planning to visit the area or have summer property there, below are a few things you need to know about these ongoing fires.

Forest fire mapWhere are forest fires happening?

Ontario's Ministry of Natural Resources' forest fire info map shows fires, as of midday Aug. 11, happening in these areas:

A 1.6-hectare fire is listed as "under control," north of Head Lake in the Queen Elizabeth II Headlands. It began Aug. 8.A 4.5-hectare fire is "under control" just west of Head Lake, It began Aug. 8.A 27-hectare fire is listed as "not under control" east of Burnt River, north of Bobcaygen. It began Aug. 9.A 12.8-hectare fire is listed as "not under control" in Hastings County, between Marmora and Bancroft. It began Aug. 9.

There's another forest fire reported just north of the community of Eldon, near the border with Simcoe County and Durham region. This one is reported to have started today and measures five hectares in size.

A hectare is 10,000 square metres, or an area equal to a square with 100-metre sides, about the size of nearly two NFL football fields.

Extreme forest fire danger rating

A large swath of land in Ontario, generally between Kawartha Lakes to the west, Carleton Place to the east, Mattawa to the north, and the counties of Hastings, Lennox and Addington, and Frontenac to the south, is under an extreme forest fire danger rating.

27-hectare fire

The Kawartha Lakes Fire Rescue Service had been working to contain the 27-hectare forest fire since Friday and the Ministry of Natural Resources is leading efforts due to the significant size of the blaze, City of Kawartha Lakes officials told Metroland.

The 27-hectare fire is roughly about the size of 50 NFL football fields.

Aerial water support, including water bombers, have also been targeting the most active fire zones since Sunday.

Fortunately, the area of this blaze is fairly remote so no evacuation orders have been issued.

Avoid Burnt River area

While there has been no evacuation order, residents and visitors are urged to avoid the Burnt River area.

As of Monday morning, a road closure remains in effect on County Road 49 between County Road 121 and Bury's Green until further notice.

There's also a total fire ban across the city of Kawartha Lakes.

No drones allowed

Residents are also reminded to not fly a drone within nine kilometres of a fire zone as it may interfere with the operation of water bombers and place pilots at risk.

How to check status of fires

The Ministry of Natural Resources operates a Forest Fire Info Map.

Residents can check the map for the status of current forest fires and their locations and size.

- With files from Todd Vandonk

urn:contentItem:6GGN-BCW3-RXND-D25H-00000-00Kawartha Lakes fires: How to see where fires are burning and which areas to avoid2025-08-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Kawartha Lakes fires: How to see where fires are burning and which areas to avoidMetroland Staff

Parts of Kawartha Lakes and surrounding communities are experiencing forest fires, which have been happening for several days and are continuing today (Monday, Aug. 11).

If you are planning to visit the area or have summer property there, below are a few things you need to know about these ongoing fires.

Forest fire mapWhere are forest fires happening?

Ontario's Ministry of Natural Resources' forest fire info map shows fires, as of midday Aug. 11, happening in these areas:

A 1.6-hectare fire is listed as "under control," north of Head Lake in the Queen Elizabeth II Headlands. It began Aug. 8.A 4.5-hectare fire is "under control" just west of Head Lake, It began Aug. 8.A 27-hectare fire is listed as "not under control" east of Burnt River, north of Bobcaygen. It began Aug. 9.A 12.8-hectare fire is listed as "not under control" in Hastings County, between Marmora and Bancroft. It began Aug. 9.

There's another forest fire reported just north of the community of Eldon, near the border with Simcoe County and Durham region. This one is reported to have started today and measures five hectares in size.

A hectare is 10,000 square metres, or an area equal to a square with 100-metre sides, about the size of nearly two NFL football fields.

Extreme forest fire danger rating

A large swath of land in Ontario, generally between Kawartha Lakes to the west, Carleton Place to the east, Mattawa to the north, and the counties of Hastings, Lennox and Addington, and Frontenac to the south, is under an extreme forest fire danger rating.

27-hectare fire

The Kawartha Lakes Fire Rescue Service had been working to contain the 27-hectare forest fire since Friday and the Ministry of Natural Resources is leading efforts due to the significant size of the blaze, City of Kawartha Lakes officials told Metroland.

The 27-hectare fire is roughly about the size of 50 NFL football fields.

Aerial water support, including water bombers, have also been targeting the most active fire zones since Sunday.

Fortunately, the area of this blaze is fairly remote so no evacuation orders have been issued.

Avoid Burnt River area

While there has been no evacuation order, residents and visitors are urged to avoid the Burnt River area.

As of Monday morning, a road closure remains in effect on County Road 49 between County Road 121 and Bury's Green until further notice.

There's also a total fire ban across the city of Kawartha Lakes.

No drones allowed

Residents are also reminded to not fly a drone within nine kilometres of a fire zone as it may interfere with the operation of water bombers and place pilots at risk.

How to check status of fires

The Ministry of Natural Resources operates a Forest Fire Info Map.

Residents can check the map for the status of current forest fires and their locations and size.

- With files from Todd Vandonk

urn:contentItem:6GGN-BCW3-RXND-D25X-00000-00Kawartha Lakes fires: How to see where fires are burning and which areas to avoid2025-08-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Kawartha Lakes fires: How to see where fires are burning and which areas to avoidMetroland Staff

Parts of Kawartha Lakes and surrounding communities are experiencing forest fires, which have been happening for several days and are continuing today (Monday, Aug. 11).

If you are planning to visit the area or have summer property there, below are a few things you need to know about these ongoing fires.

Forest fire mapWhere are forest fires happening?

Ontario's Ministry of Natural Resources' forest fire info map shows fires, as of midday Aug. 11, happening in these areas:

A 1.6-hectare fire is listed as "under control," north of Head Lake in the Queen Elizabeth II Headlands. It began Aug. 8.A 4.5-hectare fire is "under control" just west of Head Lake, It began Aug. 8.A 27-hectare fire is listed as "not under control" east of Burnt River, north of Bobcaygen. It began Aug. 9.A 12.8-hectare fire is listed as "not under control" in Hastings County, between Marmora and Bancroft. It began Aug. 9.

There's another forest fire reported just north of the community of Eldon, near the border with Simcoe County and Durham region. This one is reported to have started today and measures five hectares in size.

A hectare is 10,000 square metres, or an area equal to a square with 100-metre sides, about the size of nearly two NFL football fields.

Extreme forest fire danger rating

A large swath of land in Ontario, generally between Kawartha Lakes to the west, Carleton Place to the east, Mattawa to the north, and the counties of Hastings, Lennox and Addington, and Frontenac to the south, is under an extreme forest fire danger rating.

27-hectare fire

The Kawartha Lakes Fire Rescue Service had been working to contain the 27-hectare forest fire since Friday and the Ministry of Natural Resources is leading efforts due to the significant size of the blaze, City of Kawartha Lakes officials told Metroland.

The 27-hectare fire is roughly about the size of 50 NFL football fields.

Aerial water support, including water bombers, have also been targeting the most active fire zones since Sunday.

Fortunately, the area of this blaze is fairly remote so no evacuation orders have been issued.

Avoid Burnt River area

While there has been no evacuation order, residents and visitors are urged to avoid the Burnt River area.

As of Monday morning, a road closure remains in effect on County Road 49 between County Road 121 and Bury's Green until further notice.

There's also a total fire ban across the city of Kawartha Lakes.

No drones allowed

Residents are also reminded to not fly a drone within nine kilometres of a fire zone as it may interfere with the operation of water bombers and place pilots at risk.

How to check status of fires

The Ministry of Natural Resources operates a Forest Fire Info Map.

Residents can check the map for the status of current forest fires and their locations and size.

- With files from Todd Vandonk

urn:contentItem:6G69-0D83-RW4W-N3YW-00000-00Wanted man who lit signal fire rescued from mountainside near Hope forest fire2025-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisWanted man who lit signal fire rescued from mountainside near Hope forest fire

A wanted man, who reportedly lit a signal fire which got away from him, had to be rescued by helicopter from a mountainside in Hope on Thursday.

The incident unfolded throughout the day in Silver Creek, near exit 168 off Highway 1 on July 3.

The man was stuck on the mountain that morning so he lit a signal fire which "got away on him," said Daryn Berry, director of maintenance with Valley Helicopters.

"Through the day people could hear him calling for help," Berry said.

Hope RCMP were called to the 19000 block of Klassen Road to assist other first responders with an active wildfire on the mountainside. BC Wildfire Service lists the fire as human-caused.

"During the course of this response, a man could be heard yelling for help in the same area," Sgt. Mike Sargent with Hope RCMP stated in an email to The Chilliwack Progress.

Hope Search and Rescue, along with Chilliwack Search and Rescue, were called out to rescue him around 6:30 p.m.

"Once the wildfire was controlled, Hope and Chilliwack Search and Rescue located a 27-year-old man stranded along one of the cliff faces," Sargent said.

Collaborating with Valley Helicopters and pilot/owner Brad Fandrich, the search-and-rescue teams performed a long-line rescue to pluck the uninjured man from the mountainside.

"The man was determined to have several outstanding warrants for his arrest. Cayden Blackwell was taken into custody and will appear in court today (July 4)," Sargent said.

Blackwell is wanted for assaulting a peace officer, possession of stolen property over $5,000, resisting/obstructing a peace officer, and driving while prohibited, according to a Metro Vancouver Crime Stoppers notice from Dec. 27, 2024.

"The cause of the wildfire remains under investigation," Sargent added.

Before rescuing the man in the evening, the Valley Helicopters team was helping to extinguish the forest fire from above after it was spotted early that morning.

Berry said Thursday was "just another day."

urn:contentItem:6H3G-YCC3-RSK1-R02M-00000-00Forest fires burned 8 times more area this year than last2025-10-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSForest fires burned 8 times more area this year than lastMatt Prokopchuk, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterTBnewswatch.com

DRYDEN — Wildland fire crews were kept “very busy” throughout the 2025 forest fire season as Northwestern Ontario saw over 560,000 hectares go up in flames.

“It would be fair to call the 2025 wildland fire season a very busy one in the Northwest,” said Chris Marchand, a fire information officer with the Ministry of Natural Resources’s regional fire management centre in Dryden.

“Often in the spring, you hear us speak of the volatility of spring fire hazard conditions,” he continued.

“And this year, from about the second week of May, it really provided a good demonstration of how a few weeks of dry weather combined with high winds and low humidity can really produce extreme fire behaviour in forests that haven't greened up yet.”

Those early conditions were the spark for a season that saw 560,234.9 hectares burned by 435 fires in the Northwest region alone. Comparatively, the Northwest’s relatively slow 2024 season saw 69,938.3 hectares burned in 218 fires.

The rolling 10-year average for hectares burned annually across the entire province currently sits at 210,234, Marchand said. That's less than half what the Northwest region alone saw this year.

About 35 per cent of the total hectares burned over the 2025 fire season (statistics are kept from Apr. 1 to Oct. 31 each year) came from one fire. Red Lake 12, which started on May 28, was finally declared out in mid-October, but not before it torched 196,974 hectares in total, Marchand said.

The fire forced the evacuations of Sandy Lake and Deer Lake First Nations, which are about 65 kilometres apart.

It was eventually declared the largest wildland fire in Ontario’s history, exceeding 2021’s Kenora 51 fire.

Kenora 20 and Nipigon 5 were other fires of note that kept firefighters busy in 2025 — particularly in June — Marchand said.

“So, very large fires building on extreme fire hazard conditions and wind events that were making those fires into larger and larger concerns,” he said.

“We had several where we would have 50 to 70 to 80 kilometre-an-hour southern winds, and most of our fires of concern this year were generated in those kinds of events.”

During the worst of the 2025 season, Marchand said Ontario was helped by fire crews from British Columbia and Wisconsin, as well as aircraft and equipment from Alberta, Quebec, New Brunswick and the United States. Once things calmed down in Ontario in August, Marchand said, resources were sent to help other provinces, like Newfoundland, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, and B.C., as well as across the border in Minnesota.

Overall, Marchand said intense years like in 2025 could happen at any time.

“What happened this season is the potential for every season — it just comes down to the weather patterns of the day, how they roll out in that early spring,” he said.

“When you have several consecutive weeks with very little precipitation combined with high winds, that is a recipe for the kind of situation we found ourselves in this year,” Marchand continued.

“And it's a potential that could happen every year.”

urn:contentItem:6H0Y-9RF3-S7VN-F1YX-00000-00Nottingham Forest fires manager Ange Postecoglou minutes after 3-0 loss to Chelsea2025-10-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisSPORTSNottingham Forest fires manager Ange Postecoglou minutes after 3-0 loss to ChelseaSteve DouglasThe Associated Press

Nottingham Forest fired manager Ange Postecoglou around 20 minutes after a 3-0 loss to Chelsea on Saturday and just 39 days after the Australian took over.

Postecoglou didn’t win any of his eight matches in charge after replacing Nuno Espirito Santo on Sept. 9 and owner Evangelos Marinakis made a ruthless call after Forest's fourth straight loss in all competitions.

“Nottingham Forest Football Club can confirm that after a series of disappointing results and performances, Ange Postecoglou has been relieved of his duties as head coach with immediate effect,” a statement read.

“The club will make no further comment at this time.”

It was Postecoglou's first job since being fired by Tottenham at the end of last season despite leading Spurs to the Europa League title to break their 17-year trophy drought.

Forest lost six and drew the other two of its eight games under Postecoglou. That included four losses from five in the league, scoring just one goal in the process, to leave Forest hovering just above the bottom three.

Nuno was fired despite leading Forest into Europe following a very public falling-out with Marinakis, reportedly stemming from a breakdown in relations with the club’s recently hired global head of football, Edu Gaspar.

Postecoglou seemed an odd choice as the replacement, given his preferred style of play — on the front foot and attacking — differed to Nuno's and the squad in place at the City Ground.

If the idea was for Postecoglou to bring a more expansive approach to Forest, it didn't materialize. In five league games under the Australian, the team scored one goal.

There were loud jeers at the fulltime whistle at the Chelsea game.

Who next?

There was no immediate word of a replacement but British media has already reported that Sean Dyche, the former Burnley and Everton manager, was in line to take over should Forest fire Postecoglou.

Dyche was sacked by Everton in January. He was a youth-team player at Forest before a career spent at lower-league clubs.

His direct and pragmatic playing style is more similar to Nuno's than Postecoglou's.

urn:contentItem:6G3S-R1H3-RVMP-K125-00000-00Some residents allowed to return after forest fire in Halifax area prompts evacuation2025-06-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisATLANTICSome residents allowed to return after forest fire in Halifax area prompts evacuationThe Canadian Press

MUSQUODOBOIT HARBOUR - Halifax officials say some people who had to flee a forest fire on Sunday afternoon were being allowed back home, with provincial officials noting rain was falling and the blaze was being held.

RCMP began helping evacuate people earlier in the day after issuing a statement about a forest fire in Musquodoboit Harbour, about 45 kilometres east of downtown Halifax, and police also asked other residents to avoid the area.

Later, the Halifax Regional Municipality said some of the evacuees would be permitted to return home, while an evacuation centre would be opening for those not being allowed back.

Nova Scotia's Natural Resources department posted to social media late Sunday that the fire was being held at about 30 hectares in size and that rain was falling.

Fifteen firefighters would remain at the scene until dark, the department said, and would return Monday. It said a helicopter that was assisting the firefighters was leaving the scene.

RCMP spokesperson Guillaume Tremblay had been unable to comment on how many residents had been asked to leave their homes as of late Sunday afternoon. 

A spokesman with the Halifax Professional Fire Fighters said in an emailed statement that the fire conditions were "serious, fuelled by thick brush, dry vegetation, and gusty winds." It said crews had been pulled from the woods for safety and were focusing on structure protection.

But a social media post from the union late Sunday noted the situation had improved.

"Rain has arrived in the area and fire crews have made strong progress. The situation has stabilized, and resources are now being gradually released from the scene," the post on X said.

Halifax firefighters and the RCMP were to remain in the area overnight to monitor the situation, a news release from the Halifax Regional Municipality said. 

The municipality also advised residents close to the fire to close all windows and doors, shut down air exchangers and stay inside until air quality conditions improve.

A comfort centre has been opened at the Eastern Shore Community Centre in Musquodoboit Harbour, and the municipality said the centre will also serve as an evacuation centre for people unable to return home.

A 2023 wildfire in the western suburbs of Halifax destroyed 200 structures, including 151 homes. A heat dome and tinder-dry forests at the time fed the blaze, which forced more than 16,000 people to evacuate, with many evacuees encountering traffic jams as they fled.

This report by The Canadian Press was first published June 22, 2025. 

— By Lyndsay Armstrong in Halifax.

urn:contentItem:6GY2-SBB3-RS80-H1DD-00000-00Hikers can be citizen scientists in photo project documenting forest regrowth in Jasper2025-10-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisHikers can be citizen scientists in photo project documenting forest regrowth in Jasper

As visitors at Old Fort Point look out at the mosaic of burnt patches of forest from the Jasper wildfire, they see a vastly different landscape than they would have before July 2024. But that same barren view looks strikingly similar to photos taken in the early 1900s.

Now, as the Jasper landscape begins to regenerate in the wake of last year's massive wildfire, people hiking the popular trail are getting the opportunity to participate in a citizen science project to help document the area's rebirth.

"We get to see the landscape change before our eyes and be a part of it, and I think that's probably really rare and unique and different," said Kevin Gedling, a Parks Canada communications and engagement officer.

Parks Canada and the University of Waterloo have teamed up to crowdsource photos from three locations on the hike - a view from the summit facing north, a panoramic view facing south, and a close-up shot of vegetation on the backside.

The project uses GeoReach, a University of Waterloo initiative that uses standardized imagery data to track changes in landforms across Canada, including glaciers, rivers, marshes, coastal shores, and now, post-forest fire regrowth.

Repeat photography is a method researchers use to assess how landspaces change and grow, by replicating certain aspects of an existing photo for basic comparison.

This summer Parks Canada installed three cellphone stands, each with a cradle and window for the camera, along the popular 3.8-kilometre hike, which starts just east of the Jasper townsite. 

Visitors will take a photo from one of the stations, then scan the QR code to directly upload a photo, or visit the GeoReach website to share their photo with researchers at the University of Waterloo, citizen science groups and the general public. The website includes a gallery, displaying other photos uploaded to the site.

"It gives a really good opportunity for visitors and everyday people to just connect with the landscape and to connect with that process of ecological integrity monitoring and citizen science," Gedling said.

This summer saw several new signs of life, with vibrant grass growing around the dead trees and wildlife moving through the landscape.

Purple fleabane and yellow arnica were among the first plants to crop up into the charred landscape, said Gedling. 

A few fireweed plants have also been spotted, he said. The purple flowering plants are a sign of forest regeneration after a fire, and Gedling said he expects that, in a few years, it will be thriving in the nutrient-dense soil created by the fire.

Some sections of the Old Fort Point trail still have stands of aspen trees that appear intact but were essentially "baked to death" on the inside from the heat of the wildfire, said Gedling..

He also pointed out aspen "suckers," some of which are already almost a metre tall, that use the existing root systems to regenerate without seeds.

The fresh grass that grows post-fire is better for the animals that eat it, said Jack Bentley, a Parks Canada interpreter. 

He said the heat of the forest fire gives a response to the grasses, "to come back even faster so they grow even more nutritious which is good for all of the other species around who eat that grass like the elk and the deer."

The landscape is back to "square one," said Gedling, meaning it is now more of a grassland ecosystem, with deciduous trees as opposed to the coniferous-heavy forest that burned. 

WATCH | Parks Canada asking hikers to help with a research project:

Old Fort Point is part of the montane ecosystem of the landscape - meaning the valley bottom - is "completely dependent on forest fires."

Gedling said wildfires are part of a healthy cycle for a forest, although he acknowledges the devastation it brought to people who fought the fire and who live or work in Jasper.

The Jasper wildfire complex destroyed one-third of the townsite's structures and displaced 2,000 people. One firefighter died from being struck by a fallen tree.

"But, you know, as far as a natural process is concerned, this is literally one of the better things that can happen to it," he said.

urn:contentItem:6FYY-7X33-RRJX-82J0-00000-00Forest fire near Deer Lake now simply huge2025-06-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSForest fire near Deer Lake now simply hugeMike Stimpson, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterThunder Bay Source

DEER LAKE – The forest fire west of Wabaseemoong is no longer the largest in Northwestern Ontario now that a blaze farther north has grown to more than 65,000 hectares.

The Red Lake 12 fire that caused the evacuation of Deer Lake First Nation last week was blanketing 65,186 hectares as of Wednesday afternoon, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources. That’s more than 3.5 times the size estimated on Monday.

Smoke from fires to the west hurt the ministry’s ability “to monitor the growth of Red Lake 12 consistently throughout the operational window,” MNR fire information officer Allison Lake told Newswatch in an email.

“After several days of reduced visibility, conditions improved, allowing for high-level infrared scanning of wildland fire Red Lake 12.

“As a result of the scanning, the fire has now been remapped at 65,186 hectares, which accounts for growth that has occurred over the past few days.”

Lake said fire rangers have succeeded in “pushing into the fire’s perimeter” and keeping it away from Deer Lake buildings.

“Sprinkler protection for the community is now in place,” she added, “and FireRanger crews are working hard to maintain and monitor the protection of the buildings and infrastructure within the Deer Lake community.”

There are 86 MNR fire personnel dedicated to Red Lake 12, she said.

The previously largest fire in the Northwest region, the Kenora 20 fire that gave rise to an evacuation of Wabaseemoong Independent Nations in mid-May, was pegged at 36,000 hectares due to growth in its Manitoba portion.

Meanwhile, the MNR estimated the Nipigon 5 forest fire near Webequie First Nation had grown to more than 8,500 hectares by Tuesday evening from 7,500 on Monday.

The MNR’s latest fire updates declare the status of the Red Lake 12, Kenora 20 and Nipigon 5 forest fires as “not under control.”

Webequie declared a state of emergency late last week and is evacuating residents.

The MNR reported four new fires Tuesday, one of them being 0.7 hectares in area and less than a kilometre from the Pickle Lake townsite but under control.

The Northwestern Health Unit advised in a news release that health risks increase with smoke from wildfires.

“During heavy smoke conditions, reduce or reschedule outdoor strenuous activities,” the health unit’s release said.

“Some people are more likely to experience health effects when exposed to wildfire smoke, including those aged 65 and older, pregnant people, infants and young children, people with an existing illness or chronic health condition, and people who work outdoors.”

urn:contentItem:6H4K-2K03-S1R3-70CR-00000-00Ford's flip-flop betrays taxpayers2025-11-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisEDITORIALPg. A12Ford's flip-flop betrays taxpayersNoah Jarvis Noah Jarvis is the Ontario director of the Canadian Taxpayers Federation.

Premier Doug Ford has broken his promise to taxpayers by making the political welfare scheme permanent.

Ontario's political welfare scheme, also known as the per-vote subsidy, gives parties $2.54 each year for every vote they received in the previous general election. This takes tens of millions of dollars from taxpayer coffers so politicians can buy lawn signs and air attack ads against one another.

The Ford of 2018 understood that the government should not be funnelling taxpayer dollars to political parties for their own benefit.

"I do not believe the government should be taking money from hard-working taxpayers and giving it to political parties," Ford said. "Corporate welfare is wrong, and political party welfare is equally wrong; I will put an end to both.

"That is why when I am elected premier I will stand up for all Ontario taxpayers and eliminate the per-vote subsidy given to political parties in Ontario."

Here's how it works. If you donate $1,000 to a political party in Ontario, your charitable tax credit will be $625. So political donors can get more than half of their money back. That's a good deal. If you give that same $1,000 to the Red Cross instead, the tax credit is only $361. Apparently, Ontario politicians think political donations are about twice as important as helping out with little things like forest-fire evacuations.

These generous political credits allow the major parties to rake-in millions of dollars each year from their supporters.

In 2024, the Progressive Conservative Party managed to raise $13.3 million, while their rivals in the Liberals and NDP raised $4.4 million and $4.1 million respectively. These are contributions from donors who truly believe in the cause of their party, not government subsidies. With all the money these parties are raking in, they don't need subsidies from taxpayers.

Ford's past acknowledgment of the problems with political welfare makes it frustrating that his government has repeatedly maintained the per-vote subsidy despite several opportunities to can the program.

As the per-vote subsidy was set to expire in 2021, Ford preserved the political welfare program because of the pandemic. With the same opportunity before him in 2024, Ford once again maintained the status-quo even though the pandemic was over. Now, the Ford government is making the per-vote subsidy a permanent program.

As a result, Ontario's major parties will share out $12.3 million worth of subsidies. The PCs will take $5.3 million. The Liberals will take $3.6 million while the NDP will take around $2.5 million.

Ford was hostile to political welfare when it was easiest to oppose as a candidate for his party's leadership. But since acquiring the keys to the premier's office and his party becoming the primary beneficiary of the per-vote subsidy, Ford is suddenly the province's biggest champion of political welfare.

Critics might say the per-vote subsidy is "good for democracy," preventing special interests from gaining undue influence with politicians. But there are already strict donation limits and reporting requirements. And the per-vote subsidy creates a structural disadvantage for independent candidates and new parties. The subsidies rig the political system in favour of the province's legacy parties, making it harder for newcomer parties to usurp them.

If the parties want more money, they should convince ordinary Ontarians to make donations. And if they don't, so be it. Taxpayers concerned with the cost of living aren't going to bed worrying if the PCs, Liberals or NDP have enough money to drop pamphlets in their mailboxes.

If Ford truly wants to run a fiscally responsible government, the easiest program to go after is the political welfare scheme. Ford needs to get back in tune with the 2018 version of himself and reverse his government's plan to make the per-vote subsidy scheme permanent.

Noah Jarvis is the Ontario director of the Canadian Taxpayers Federation.

urn:contentItem:6H66-P723-RXFC-G150-00000-00Local spending builds stronger communities2025-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Local spending builds stronger communitiesSusie Quinn; Austin Kelly

Local businesses define a community. And shopping local creates a ripple effect that impacts the economy in a circular manner.

The website bcbuylocal.com notes that local businesses create nearly five times the impact of multinational companies.

“Local retailers recirculate 63 per cent of the money spent in their shops into the local economy, compared to just 14 per cent at chain stores, while local suppliers.re-circulate 33 per cent back into the local economy compared to 19 per cent for chain stores,” the website said.

When it comes to supporting local businesses, Jolleen Dick, Alberni Valley Chamber of Commerce CEO said every dollar kept in Alberni helps Alberni.

“We have local shops investing in our not-forprofit organizations, our sports teams and to causes. You’re not going to have the big corporations care about these areas where support’s needed,” she said.

Dick said local businesses are able to build relationships with the communities they operate in, which helps them support the community and building connections.

“Shop owners are not just selling their products and services, they’re building a relationship and they know what’s happening in your life if you’re a frequent shopper,” she said.

“It’s truly an ecosystem of relationships and support here.”

One of Alberni’s greatest strengths is local businesses support one another, Dick said. She gave the example of the recent fire at Dog Mountain Brewing and how fellow brewery Twin City Brewing stepped up to start a fundraiser for them.

“I think in Port Alberni it might feel like you’re alone but when you need help, people will step up to the plate and support you,” she said.

“‘Port Alberni can be difficult on itself,” said Lori Camire, general manager of Community Futures Alberni-Clayoquot. “There’s nothing to indicate to us that our community is not doing well. Overall the economy is showing to be strong and that gives us comfort,” she added.

Dick agreed, saying that given what’s happening around the world, Port Alberni’s economy feels good.

“Down at Harbour Quay you have a row of women-owned businesses from Pinto (Goods and Refillery) to West Hump Gear Exchange to The Broken Bow,” she said. “To see a row of women-owned businesses is exciting and good indicator that people believe in Port Alberni.”

One of the biggest economic boons for the city is the thousands of tourists who travel through Port Alberni. Dick said visitors to the city spend their money at local businesses and help keep them going.

But one of the biggest challenge facing businesses in Port Alberni Canada’s southern neighbours, she said.

“When you have this much uncertainty, this much flip-flopping, this much reactionary behaviour from the United States government on what Canada does or does not do, it’s created this environment of uncertainty where consumers are holding onto their funds and they’re not too sure if they to,” she said. She added that people are starting to get comfortable spending money again after adjusting to the past year of uncertainty.

But that isn’t the only challenge for local businesses, Dick says business owners have to manage more regulations from all levels of government, which is hurting their ability to do business.

“And it’s getting harder and harder to keep up so businesses have to adapt and change and some might not be able to,” she said.

Since 2019 businesses in Alberni have faced a lot of uncertainty:from the COVID-19 pandemic to 2023’s forest fire which closed the highway and now battling the uncertainty of tariffs.

“There is incredible grit of our businesses who pivot and adapt and make it work not just for themselves, but for their teams and to be a part of the community,” Dick said. “We’re in it together here in Port Alberni.”

The Port Alberni Chamber of Commerce’s goal is to fight for those businesses.

“We’re the voice of business for the Alberni Valley,” Dick said. “‘The purpose of the chamber of commerce is to be that umbrella of all businesses, to use that voice collectively and challenge policy that is obstructive to doing business.”

Dick is confident that whatever is thrown at Port Alberni’s local economy, residents and business owners will always step up to support the community.

“‘We are truly a community with heart and we’re resilient and we’ll make it through anything,” she said.

We would like to acknowledge the Alberni Valley Chamber of Commerce as our Shop Local initiative title sponsor. The chamber will provide a prize package to those entering our Shop Local, Shop Here contest atwww.albernivalleynews.com/contests, beginning Nov. 5, 2025. Rules and regulations will be posted on the contest link.

It’s truly an ecosystem of relationships and support here. – Jolleen Dick

urn:contentItem:6H5M-TWK3-SHSC-P3F0-00000-00Homeowner insurance rates based on numerous factors insurance broker reveals2025-11-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSHomeowner insurance rates based on numerous factors insurance broker revealsJill Westerman, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterNWT News/North

If homeowners are feeling the pinch in their pocketbooks from rising insurance rates in Yellowknife and the South Slave region, it may not have as much to do with the risk of wildfires as they may think, says an insurance broker with numerous Northern clients.

“Part of it is going to have to do with availability of trades material and the cost to build the house,” Richard Wahl, a senior account executive with NationNorth in Winnipeg, and a member of the Canadian Broker Network.

“When you're in a more metropolitan area, like Edmonton, Calgary, Winnipeg, or Vancouver, there's guys that build houses all over the place. Now, carpenters, framers, electricians, plumbers and the like, all make more money up in these Northern areas simply because there's not as many trades, and the cost of living dictates how much they're going to get paid to do the job, plus the availability of materials, and that sort of thing. So that plays a large part.

“So basically, insurance is rated at the replacement cost of the home,” Wahl said.

As a result, he said there would be a “substantial” difference in the price of Northern insurance.

And because houses are insured at their replacement cost, Wahl said insurance companies are “on the hook to rebuild that house”, regardless of the cost.

“So everything that factors into these costs are all associated with the cost to build that home, plus certain risk factors. There's very little chance of a forest fire burning a house down in, say, Calgary, Edmonton, or Winnipeg, but in Yellowknife, there is an off chance.

“But I get calls from clients all the time going, ‘Yeah, my insurance company told me that it's because of the forest fires’, but maybe a small amount.

“It has more to do with the cost to build that home, to rebuild that house.”

Shopping around

Wahl said, however, that there are some insurance companies using forest fires as an excuse to increase insurance rates.

“Some companies are doubling their costs, which is crazy. I mean, I've managed to save people a lot of money in some situations, and in other situations, you can't. It seems some of these insurers, not brokers like myself, but some of these insurers, are selectively sending these crazy increases to some folks.

“There's a financial institution that comes to mind where I had one lady, her policy went from $7,000 a year, which was high already, to over $14,000. So that, to me, is unacceptable.”

Wahl said while annual increases due to inflation are expected, usually between four and six per cent, the doubling of premiums is “not right”.

While Wahl said while there are options for homeowners to ensure they get a fair rate, depending on the type of home they have or where it is located, they can fall into the unprotected category, such as on several streets near Yellowknife’s Grace Lake, for example.

Homeowners can fall into that category when they are not within a certain distance from a fire hydrant or fire hall.

Other factors that affect the cost of insurance can be the home’s roof material, the heating source, age, and plumbing and electrical material, he said.

“But when somebody tells me that their premium has doubled, that's nuts,” he said.

Choosing wisely

Wahl recalled an insurance provider a few years ago that doubled or tripled its rates on mobile homes - all because they did not to want to insure them anymore.

“But most people just can't afford that, so they needed to seek alternatives, and it was all because they did not want to insure mobile homes anymore. So that's what they did,

increase the rate. They just put their rates up to a point where, basically, it's unaffordable.

“I won't use them for that reason, because it wasn't a morally correct decision to make, in my opinion, to just bail on these people that have been your client for 10 years and all of a sudden now you're kind of hanging them out to dry. What do they do, mobile home or not?” he said.

South of the lake, Wahl said insurance costs would be comparable to those in the Yellowknife area for the same reasons.

In Nunavut territory, where there is no road access, he said insurance costs would be even higher because access is limited to air or sealift for housing materials.

“In Iqaluit, I’ve got some home insurance policies that are in excess of $12 - 14,000 just because of the cost to get material and trades up there. And then when you get up to places like Gjoa Haven or Whale Cove it’s even more,” he said.

“They’ve got it tough up there without a doubt.”

NNSL reached out to several Yellowknife realtors for comment but received no response.

urn:contentItem:6H27-4723-RXKP-N4DX-00000-00First phase of Waasigan transmission line to be completed by end of 20262025-10-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSFirst phase of Waasigan transmission line to be completed by end of 2026Matt Prokopchuk, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterTBnewswatch.com

ATIKOKAN — The first phase of the Waasigan transmission line project from Shuniah to Atikokan is now slated to go live by the end of 2026, Hydro One says.

Sonny Karunakaran, Hydro One’s vice president of strategic projects and partnerships, told Dougall Media on Thursday that the overall project — which includes a second phase from Atikokan to Dryden — is still scheduled for completion by the end of 2027.

The first poles for the 230 kilovolt lines, designed to transmit 350 megawatts of power, went up in October.

“The requirement from the (Independent) Electricity System Operator was to try and bring it in as close to the end of 2025 as possible, and the overall project in by the end of 2027, which is what we're on track to do,” Karunakaran said.

A briefing note from Fort William First Nation, one of nine First Nations that have partnered with Hydro One on the Waasigan line, said construction got off to a slow start in 2025, with a late spring thaw and break up, and early forest fire activity at the Sapawe work camp in May.

The mayor of Atikokan said he’s excited about the ongoing work, adding that he attended a celebration of the first pole going up earlier in October.

Rob Ferguson told Newswatch the project will have many long-term benefits for Atikokan.

“It's going to be 350 megawatts that we can import into Atikokan or export out of Atikokan,” he said, adding that the existing lines that run into the town have prevented the community from partnering with power companies during the current round of proposals being taken by the IESO as it seeks more sources of electricity for the province.

“Where they're looking for more generation, Atikokan was never able to look at that because we were bottled and we couldn't get the power out of Atikokan,” Ferguson said.

“So now with the Waasigan, it's going to give us an opportunity to have generating projects and we can help power the Northwest.”

Karunakaran said the new lines are double-circuit lines, meaning electricity can flow in two directions. That, he said, allows any power generation in a given area to be exported for revenue.

“If you want to think of an interconnected electricity system, you have generation at various points through the electricity system,” he said. “Sometimes there's localized generation that's up in the Northwest region — this line can be used to move that power across to wherever the load is required at the time.”

“There could be the need in another region whereby the power from this region is moved across to there, and likewise, when there's power available elsewhere in the network — and if it's required here by load in this region — this line will actually bring the clean reliable energy forward for it.”

“We're looking for opportunities, and we've had some developers very interested in Atikokan, and the main reason is because the Waasigan power lines coming in,” Ferguson said.

urn:contentItem:6GV8-1X23-S4JS-X05J-00000-00Hell comes to Haileybury2025-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. A4Hell comes to HaileyburyRosemary Ganley OPINION

I'm taking my own advice and peering more closely at my family's past.

This has been aided in large part by a recent serendipitous event when I was having tea at the home of friend Gloria Macdonald and noticed a huge glossy blue book on her table, entitled "The Great Fire of 1922".

Gloria, who had lived her first 13 years in the northern Ontario mining town of Kirkland Lake, where I had spent my childhood and youth before her, has maintained a keen interest in the town, the whole area and its history.

The disaster, which took 44 lives, started in Haileybury after a hot dry summer and fall. The collected testimony of survivors, compiled recently by Deborah Ranchuk, with many ominous photos, gives a grainy realism to the story which galvanized the province and indeed the country.

The Haileybury Fire was considered one of the 10 worst disasters in Canadian history. It affected 18 townships in the district of Temiskaming. Towns, villages and hamlets with such names as North Cobalt, Uno Park, Charlton, Thornloe, Heaslip, New Liskeard and Engelhart, along with their farms, animals and crops, were burned out. Six hundred and fifty square miles were wracked by the huge, devastating forest fire in one afternoon on Oct. 4, 1922.

To the everlasting credit of the Haileybury Heritage Museum, this commemorative book was published 100 years after the disaster. It collected 160 photos and scores of touching recollections, largely from children at the time, now writing from a terrified memory.

Gloria Macdonald acquired the book in 2022, and noticed that my mother, Marjorie Hogg Burns, who was an 18-year-old schoolteacher, born in New Liskeard, and having trained at North Bay Teachers College, was in charge of the all-age school in the hamlet of Whitewood Grove, and had been a heroine of the fire. She was even mentioned in dispatches in the Globe and Mail of the time.

It seems the teacher-teenager covered her pupils with wet blankets and herded them outside dousing sparks as they landed. Many thousands, closer to the shores of Lake Temiskaming, sought refuge in the lake.

Haileybury now has a fitting outdoor sculpture, done by artist Ernie Fauvelle, showing a kneeling man handing a swaddled child into the arms of a woman who stands knee-deep in the lake.

Six thousand people were left homeless by the fire. Hearing that, kind Torontonians sent 150 streetcars by rail which served as homes for up to three years. The day after the fire swept through, snow fell. Winter clothing arrived, too, on one of two rail lines: the Temiskaming and Northern Ontario Railway (T&NO), from Toronto to Cochrane via North Bay, and the CNR, west of it, from Toronto to Sudbury.

I found it heart-stopping reading. It was a crown forest fire, the most dangerous of the three types: ground, surface and crown. The crown type has the fearsome ability, when it reaches treetops, to create a vacuum so fierce that the fire jumps in great leaps, creating its own wind of 112 km/h.

My mother told us her beau at the time tried to ride a horse from New Liskeard along a country road engulfed in flames on both sides, to rescue her. He perished.

Some farms, which had been spared, housed up to 40 people for days.

The values of those days shine through the book. It opens with a humble prayer "Let us grow old with gladness, peace in our hearts and tolerance for the young who take our place."

I, for one, am thankful I have ancestors of this mettle and many like them, to have settled Canada. Their qualities of courage and connectedness, of simplicity and generosity are exactly what we need in 2025 as we face defining ourselves all over again.

Rosemary Ganley is a writer, activist and teacher.

urn:contentItem:6H4K-2K03-S1R3-703B-00000-00Dear Premier Ford: What ever happened to 'political party welfare is wrong?'2025-11-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisOPINION/CONTRIBUTORSPg. 1Dear Premier Ford: What ever happened to 'political party welfare is wrong?'Noah Jarvis

Premier Doug Ford has broken his promise to taxpayers by making the political welfare scheme permanent.

Ontario's political welfare scheme, also known as the per-vote subsidy, gives political parties $2.54 each year for every vote they received in previous general election. This self-serving scheme takes tens of millions of dollars from taxpayer coffers so that politicians can buy more lawn signs and air more attack ads against one another.

The Ford of 2018 understood that the government should not be funnelling taxpayer dollars to political parties for their own benefit.

"I do not believe the government should be taking money from hard-working taxpayers and giving it to political parties," Ford said. "Corporate welfare is wrong, and political party welfare is equally wrong; I will put an end to both.

"That is why when I am elected premier I will stand up for all Ontario taxpayers and eliminate the per-vote subsidy given to political parties in Ontario."

He was absolutely right.

Political parties already have the advantage of offering their donors a significant tax credit for their contributions.

Here's how it works.

If you donate $1,000 to a political party in Ontario, your charitable tax credit will be $625. So political donors can get more than half of their money back with tax breaks. That's a good deal.

If you give that same $1,000 to the Red Cross instead, the tax credit is only $361.

Apparently, Ontario politicians think political donations are about twice as important as helping out with little things like forest-fire evacuations.

These generous political credits allow the major parties to rake-in millions of dollars each year from their supporters.

In 2024, the Progressive Conservative Party managed to raise $13.3 million, while their rivals in the Liberals and NDP raised $4.4 million and $4.1 million respectively. These are contributions from donors who truly believe in the cause of their party, not government subsidies. With all the money these parties are raking in, they don't need subsidies from taxpayers.

Ford's past acknowledgment of the problems with political welfare makes it frustrating that his government has repeatedly maintained the per-vote subsidy despite several opportunities to can the program.

As the per-vote subsidy was set to expire in 2021, Ford preserved the political welfare program because of the pandemic. With the same opportunity before him in 2024, Ford once again maintained the status-quo of government subsidies to politicians even though the pandemic was over.

Now, the Ford government is making the per-vote subsidy a permanent program.

As a result, Ontario's major parties will share out $12.3 million worth of subsidies. The PCs will take $5.3 million. The Liberals will take $3.6 million while the NDP will take around $2.5 million. This doesn't even include the hundreds of thousands being shovelled to the Green Party, New Blue Party and Ontario Party.

Ford was hostile to political welfare when it was easiest to oppose as a candidate for his party's leadership. But since acquiring the keys to the premier's office and his party becoming the primary beneficiary of the per-vote subsidy, Ford is suddenly the province's biggest champion of political welfare.

Critics might say that the per-vote subsidy is "good for democracy," preventing special interests from gaining undue influence with politicians. But there are already strict donation limits and reporting requirements. And the per-vote subsidy creates a structural disadvantage for independent candidates and new parties who can only rely on supporter contributions rather than subsidies. The subsidies rig the political system in favour of the province's legacy parties, making it harder for newcomer parties to usurp them.

If the parties want more money, they should convince ordinary Ontarians to make donations. And if they don't, so be it. Taxpayers concerned with the cost of living aren't going to bed worrying if the PCs, Liberals or NDP have enough money to drop pamphlets in their mailboxes.

If Ford truly wants to run a fiscally responsible government, the easiest program to go after is the political welfare scheme. Ford needs to get back in tune with the 2018 version of himself and reverse his government's plan to make the per-vote subsidy scheme permanent.

urn:contentItem:6H4K-2K03-S1R3-709G-00000-00Dear Premier Ford: What ever happened to 'political party welfare is wrong?'2025-11-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisOPINION/CONTRIBUTORSPg. 1Dear Premier Ford: What ever happened to 'political party welfare is wrong?'Noah Jarvis

Premier Doug Ford has broken his promise to taxpayers by making the political welfare scheme permanent.

Ontario's political welfare scheme, also known as the per-vote subsidy, gives political parties $2.54 each year for every vote they received in previous general election. This self-serving scheme takes tens of millions of dollars from taxpayer coffers so that politicians can buy more lawn signs and air more attack ads against one another.

The Ford of 2018 understood that the government should not be funnelling taxpayer dollars to political parties for their own benefit.

"I do not believe the government should be taking money from hard-working taxpayers and giving it to political parties," Ford said. "Corporate welfare is wrong, and political party welfare is equally wrong; I will put an end to both.

"That is why when I am elected premier I will stand up for all Ontario taxpayers and eliminate the per-vote subsidy given to political parties in Ontario."

He was absolutely right.

Political parties already have the advantage of offering their donors a significant tax credit for their contributions.

Here's how it works.

If you donate $1,000 to a political party in Ontario, your charitable tax credit will be $625. So political donors can get more than half of their money back with tax breaks. That's a good deal.

If you give that same $1,000 to the Red Cross instead, the tax credit is only $361.

Apparently, Ontario politicians think political donations are about twice as important as helping out with little things like forest-fire evacuations.

These generous political credits allow the major parties to rake-in millions of dollars each year from their supporters.

In 2024, the Progressive Conservative Party managed to raise $13.3 million, while their rivals in the Liberals and NDP raised $4.4 million and $4.1 million respectively. These are contributions from donors who truly believe in the cause of their party, not government subsidies. With all the money these parties are raking in, they don't need subsidies from taxpayers.

Ford's past acknowledgment of the problems with political welfare makes it frustrating that his government has repeatedly maintained the per-vote subsidy despite several opportunities to can the program.

As the per-vote subsidy was set to expire in 2021, Ford preserved the political welfare program because of the pandemic. With the same opportunity before him in 2024, Ford once again maintained the status-quo of government subsidies to politicians even though the pandemic was over.

Now, the Ford government is making the per-vote subsidy a permanent program.

As a result, Ontario's major parties will share out $12.3 million worth of subsidies. The PCs will take $5.3 million. The Liberals will take $3.6 million while the NDP will take around $2.5 million. This doesn't even include the hundreds of thousands being shovelled to the Green Party, New Blue Party and Ontario Party.

Ford was hostile to political welfare when it was easiest to oppose as a candidate for his party's leadership. But since acquiring the keys to the premier's office and his party becoming the primary beneficiary of the per-vote subsidy, Ford is suddenly the province's biggest champion of political welfare.

Critics might say that the per-vote subsidy is "good for democracy," preventing special interests from gaining undue influence with politicians. But there are already strict donation limits and reporting requirements. And the per-vote subsidy creates a structural disadvantage for independent candidates and new parties who can only rely on supporter contributions rather than subsidies. The subsidies rig the political system in favour of the province's legacy parties, making it harder for newcomer parties to usurp them.

If the parties want more money, they should convince ordinary Ontarians to make donations. And if they don't, so be it. Taxpayers concerned with the cost of living aren't going to bed worrying if the PCs, Liberals or NDP have enough money to drop pamphlets in their mailboxes.

If Ford truly wants to run a fiscally responsible government, the easiest program to go after is the political welfare scheme. Ford needs to get back in tune with the 2018 version of himself and reverse his government's plan to make the per-vote subsidy scheme permanent.

urn:contentItem:6H38-JDK3-S9W1-J1C4-00000-00Yukon wildfire leader urges Ottawa to include Indigenous crews in cer tification2025-10-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Yukon wildfire leader urges Ottawa to include Indigenous crews in cer tificationJake Howarth

Chad Thomas, founder of Yukon First Nations Wildfire, met with federal leaders in Ottawa on Oct. 22 to call for national recognition of Indigenous wildfire crews and long-term funding to match the scale of Canadian wildfires.

He joined a delegation of wildfire survivors and emergency responders pressing for federal action on equipment, resources, mental health supports and Indigenous-led emergency management. The visit followed what organizers described as Canada’s second-worst wildfire season on record.

Thomas said Ottawa must remove barriers that prevent Indigenous crews from receiving national certification. Under current rules, only provinces and territories can certify wildfire personnel, a restriction that sidelines First Nations trainers and limits deployment.

“Right now, the only people that hold on to that national certification are the provinces and territories themselves and they don’t allow First Nation contractors to certify people to this high level,” Thomas said.

Beat the Heat, a Yukon First Nations Wildfire program created by Thomas, is not federally endorsed despite its rigorous training standards. He said the program is on par with the territorial one, but its graduates aren’t eligible for national deployment.

A four-part strategy was proposed to improve Indigenous emergency management, youth recruitment, standardized training, proper equipment and field experience. Without all four, Thomas said certification and retention will continue to suffer.

“If you don’t allow them to get out on the incidences and get experience to build that final piece for them to be certified, then that’s a big issue,” he said.

Retention is already a concern, according to Thomas. Many young firefighters leave First Nations crews to join provincial agencies offering better training and advancement, despite wanting to serve their own communities.

“We invest so much in recruiting and training but without experience opportunities, they can’t progress. We need to let them grow while staying with their own organizations,” Thomas said.

First Nations crews are often classified as contractors rather than first responders, a distinction that limits access to advanced training and excludes them from inter-agency coordination through the Canadian Inter-agency Forest Fire Centre (CIFFC), which oversees inter-provincial deployments.

“They’re not really contract crews, they’re First Nation first responders,” Thomas said.

“That’s something that’s always bothered me quite a bit and it’s something I’ve been advocating for a very long time.”

While provinces pay to participate in CIFFC, First Nations governments are excluded, despite managing their own wildfire crews and territories. Thomas said federal officials were receptive to his message, though surprised by the extent of the gaps.

“A lot of the information that they get fed is from provinces and territories,” he said.

Foreign fire crews from Australia, South Africa, the United States and Mexico have previously deployed under mutual aid agreements. Thomas said Canada should prioritize Indigenous crews who are trained, locally based and deeply familiar with the land.

Mental health support was also highlighted as a critical gap. Thomas said First Nations wildfire crews often go without adequate resources despite working under the same front-line conditions as territorial teams.

National coordination could help address these issues. Thomas is calling for consistent funding, regional emergency management positions and a seat at the table for Indigenous crews managing wildfire risk in their own traditional territories.

The Wildfire Awareness Society recently graded Whitehorse’s wildfire preparedness. Forest fuel management earned an A-, but city-level FireSmart efforts and evacuation planning received C and D grades, citing limited resources and public awareness.

Thomas said those findings reflect broader systemic gaps that national coordination could help close, if Indigenous crews are empowered to lead.

Contact Jake Howarth at jake.howarth@yukon-news.com

urn:contentItem:6G9H-YMV3-S3ND-333D-00000-00Forest fire haze from Indonesia detected in Malaysia2025-07-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONALForest fire haze from Indonesia detected in MalaysiaThe Associated Press

PEKANBARU, Indonesia (AP) — Haze from forest and peatland fires in some parts of Indonesia’s Sumatra island was detected in Malaysia on Sunday, officials said.

Forest and peat fires are an annual problem in Indonesia that strain relations with neighboring countries. In recent years, smoke from the fires has blanketed parts of Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia and southern Thailand.

A number of areas in Indonesia's Riau province were still covered by thick haze, although choking smoke had not been registered in the provincial capital of Pekanbaru, said Riau deputy police chief Adrianto Jossy Kusumo.

He said more than 140 forest and peatland fires were reported in the province. Rokan Hilir and Rokan Hulu districts were the worst hit areas by fires that burned about 46 hectares in the two districts, resulting in heavy haze pollution across the area that reduced visibility to as low as one kilometer (half a mile).

The figure for fires was down from 294 hotspots on Saturday after authorities managed to extinguish the fire in several places, Kusumo said.

He said haze has caused the air quality in Riau to worsen, “but overall it has not disrupted people’s lives in other areas of the province.”

However, based on satellite imagery from the Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics Agency in Pekanbaru, haze was detected moving northeastward and reaching Kemang Bay in Malaysia’s Negeri Sembilan state, said a forecaster on duty, Gita Dewi.

“It showed the haze was moving by the wind to cross Malaysia,” Dewi said. She said hotspots were also detected in other parts of West Sumatra and North Sumatra provinces, but Riau recorded the highest number of hotspots on the island of Sumatra.

Forest fires on Sumatra and Borneo islands often break out in the region during dry spells, smothering parts of nearby Singapore and Malaysia in haze.

In 2023, Indonesia which often sends apologies to its neighbors over the haze, denied that its fires were causing blankets of haze in Malaysia.

The Indonesian government usually blames plantation owners and traditional farmers for illegally setting the fires for land-clearing.

urn:contentItem:6FX9-1X43-RSWV-34T7-00000-00Canadian Gold Corp. Provides an Update on the Forest Fire Situation Near the Tartan Mine2025-05-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisCanadian Gold Corp. Provides an Update on the Forest Fire Situation Near the Tartan Mine

CANADIAN GOLD CORP ("CGC-V;STRRF-0") - Canadian Gold Corp. Provides an Update on the Forest Fire Situation - Near the Tartan Mine

Canadian Gold Corp. ("Canadian Gold" or the "Company") has temporarily suspended drilling operations at its Tartan Mine property near Flin Flon, Manitoba, due to a forest fire in the nearby vicinity.

"We have withdrawn our staff and continue to monitor our facilities remotely in accordance with local directives. Our team is in constant communication with local and provincial authorities to coordinate all efforts during this difficult time. All personnel are safe, and the Tartan facilities are secure. While all activities at the site are currently suspended, we remain hopeful that the nearby forest fire activity will not have any material impact on our Phase 4 drilling program.

All the firefighters, EMS workers, RCMP, and the great people of Flin Flon remain in our thoughts during this difficult time." - Michael Swistun, CFA, President &CEO

Canadian Gold Corp. will update the market in the event of any material change arising in relation to the forest fire situation.

For Further Information, Please Contact:

Michael Swistun, CFA

President &CEO

Canadian Gold Corp.

info@canadiangoldcorp.com

About Canadian Gold Corp.

Canadian Gold Corp. is a Canadian-based mineral exploration and development company whose objective is to expand the high-grade gold resource at the past producing Tartan Mine, located in Flin Flon, Manitoba. The historic Tartan Mine currently has a 2017 indicated mineral resource estimate of 240,000 oz gold (1,180,000 tonnes at 6.32 g/t gold) and an inferred estimate of 37,000 oz gold (240,000 tonnes at 4.89 g/t gold). The Company also holds a 100% interest in greenfields exploration properties in Ontario and Quebec adjacent to some of Canada's largest gold mines and development projects, specifically, the Canadian Malartic Mine (QC), the Hemlo Mine (ON) and Hammond Reef Project (ON). McEwen Mining Inc. (NYSE:MUX) (TSX: MUX)holds a 5.7% interest in Canadian Gold, and Robert McEwen, the founder and former CEO of Goldcorp, and Chairman and CEO of McEwen Mining, holds a 32.9% interest in Canadian Gold.

urn:contentItem:6GV8-1X23-S4JS-X06S-00000-00Hell comes to Haileybury2025-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisLIFEPg. 1Hell comes to HaileyburyRosemary Ganley

I'm taking my own advice and peering more closely at my family's past.

This has been aided in large part by a recent serendipitous event when I was having tea at the home of friend Gloria Macdonald and noticed a huge glossy blue book on her table, entitled "The Great Fire of 1922".

Gloria, who had lived her first 13 years in the northern Ontario mining town of Kirkland Lake, where I had spent my childhood and youth before her, has maintained a keen interest in the town, the whole area and its history.

The disaster, which lasted only one afternoon and took 44 lives, started in Haileybury after a hot dry summer and fall. The collected testimony of survivors, compiled recently by Deborah Ranchuk, with many ominous photos, gives a grainy realism to the story which galvanized the province and indeed the country.

The Haileybury Fire was considered one of the 10 worst disasters in Canadian history. It affected 18 townships in the district of Temiskaming. Towns, villages, and hamlets with such names as North Cobalt, Uno Park, Charlton, Thornloe, Heaslip, New Liskeard and Engelhart, along with their farms, animals and crops, were burned out. Six hundred and fifty square miles were wracked by the huge, devastating forest fire in one afternoon on Oct. 4,1922.

To the everlasting credit of the Haileybury Heritage Museum, this commemorative book was published 100 years after the disaster. It collected 160 photos and scores of touching recollections, largely from children at the time, now writing from a terrified memory.

Gloria Macdonald acquired the book in 2022, and noticed that my mother, Marjorie Hogg Burns, who was an 18-year-old schoolteacher, born in New Liskeard, and having trained at North Bay Teachers College, was in charge of the all-age school in the hamlet of Whitewood Grove, and had been a heroine of the fire. She was even mentioned in dispatches in the Globe and Mail of the time.

It seems the teacher-teenager covered her pupils with wet blankets and herded them outside dousing sparks as they landed. Many thousands, closer to the shores of Lake Temiskaming, sought refuge in the lake. Sadly, one family perished of suffocation, going down into a well.

Haileybury now has a fitting outdoor sculpture of three people, done by artist Ernie Fauvelle, showing a kneeling man handing a swaddled child into the arms of a woman who stands knee-deep in the lake. She is surrounded by stones for ballast.

Six thousand people were left homeless by the fire. Hearing that, kind Torontonians sent 150 streetcars by rail which served as homes for up to three years. The day after the fire swept through, snow fell.

Winter clothing arrived too, on one of two rail lines: the Temiskaming and Northern Ontario Railway (T&NO), from Toronto to Cochrane via North Bay, and the CNR, west of it, from Toronto to Sudbury.

I found it heart-stopping reading. It was a crown forest fire, the most dangerous of the three types: ground, surface and crown. The crown type has the fearsome ability, when it reaches treetops, to create a vacuum so fierce that the fire jumps in great leaps, creating its own wind of 70 mph.

My mother told us that her beau at the time tried to ride a horse from New Liskeard along a country road engulfed in flames on both sides, to rescue her. He perished.

Some farms, which had been spared, housed up to 40 people for days. The values of those days shine through the book. It opens with a humble prayer "Let us grow old with gladness, peace in our hearts and tolerance for the young who take our place."

I, for one, am thankful I have ancestors of this mettle and many like them, to have settled Canada. Their qualities of courage and connectedness, of simplicity and generosity are exactly what we need in 2025 as we face defining ourselves all over again.

urn:contentItem:6H1H-SGP3-S2N6-30RJ-00000-00Manitoba First Nation mourns loss of longtime fire chief instrumental in summer wildfire fight2025-10-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:04ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWS & EXECUTIVE MOVES NEWSManitoba First Nation mourns loss of longtime fire chief instrumental in summer wildfire fight

A northern Manitoba First Nation is mourning the sudden loss of its longtime fire chief, a man officials say was a beloved member of the community and instrumental in keeping people safe during this summer's devastating wildfires. 

Pimicikamak Cree Nation Fire Chief Raymond McKay "was a dedicated leader who served his Nation with unwavering courage and commitment," Manitoba Keewatinowi Okimakanak said in a Tuesday news release, announcing his death.

"His efforts during one of the most devastating wildfire seasons in Manitoba's history were instrumental in protecting lives and property across the region."

Pimicikamak Chief David Monias said in a Tuesday interview that McKay's death was sudden and unexpected, but no cause of death will be confirmed until after an autopsy is completed. 

Monias said he and many in the community, also commonly referred to as Cross Lake, are still in a state of shock, as McKay, who worked as fire chief for decades, was a cherished member of the community.

"He's been very instrumental in protecting the community, he's well-known and very active in community events," Monias said. "Normally he would be the one leading marathon runners or escorting grieving families and their processions. 

"He was somebody that people looked up to."

McKay's death comes just months after Pimicikamak Cree Nation dealt with a devastating wildfire season. 

The entire community of about 7,000, which is located about 530 kilometres north of Winnipeg, was evacuated at the end of May due to the threats from a pair of wildfires, with  community members dispersed to hotels and other shelters across Manitoba, and as far away as Niagara Falls, Ont.

Monias said McKay played a significant role in keeping both people and property safe as the fires closed in on the community. 

"It was a well-trained crew that worked with him, and when the wildfires happened he was there," he said.

"While people were fighting the forest fire, he would be doing preventative work to ensure that the community is safe and infrastructure is safe, and houses are safe."

McKay is being mourned not just in the community, but across the province and the country, Monias said.  

"He had a lot of friends out here that are really missing him, and not only was he well-known in Cross Lake, but he was well known within the firefighters across Canada."

Monias said he is also grieving the loss of a good friend in McKay.

It's too early to start thinking about who will replace him in the role of fire chief, as many are left in shock following his death, said Monias.

"It's hard to even start to comprehend that we need to do that," he said.

"It's hard to replace someone that you know so well, and has been on the job for such a long time, and who you had a relationship with as a friend."

Manitoba Keewatinowi Okimakanak, which represents First Nations in northern Manitoba, said no date for a funeral has been set yet, but there are plans in the works for a firefighter parade-style procession at McKay's funeral service, which the organization says would symbolize the "strength and sacrifice of those who serve."

Details of the funeral service will be shared with the public as soon as they are confirmed, MKO said.
